Thrush is a common yeast infection that affects men and women. It's usually harmless but it can be uncomfortable and keep coming back. It is not classed as a sexually transmitted infection (STI).

sections.title: Thrush in other areas
paragraphs: Thrush can affect other areas of skin, such as the armpits, groin and between the fingers.
This usually causes a red, itchy or painful rash that scales over with white or yellow discharge. The rash may not be so obvious on darker skin.
Sometimes thrush causes no symptoms at all.

paragraphs: You may also be able to get help from a sexual health clinic if you think you have thrush.

sections.title: What happens at your appointment
paragraphs: The GP will want to confirm it's thrush and rule out other infections.
You'll be asked about your symptoms.

sections.title: Thrush treatment
paragraphs: You'll usually need antifungal medicine to get rid of thrush. This can be a tablet you take, a tablet you insert into your vagina (pessary) or a cream to relieve the irritation.
Thrush should clear up within 7 to 14 days of starting treatment.
You do not need to treat partners unless they have symptoms.

sections.title: Recurring thrush
paragraphs: You might need to take treatment for longer (up to 6 months) if you keep getting thrush (you get it more than 4 times in 12 months).
Before you begin treatment, a GP can help identify if something is causing your thrush, such as your period or sex.
They'll recommend how often you should use treatment.

sections.title: Things you can do yourself to ease discomfort and prevent thrush returning
paragraphs: There are things you can do to ease thrush and stop it coming back.

sections.title: Do
paragraphs: use water and an emollient (like E45 cream) instead of soap to wash the affected area
dry properly after washing
wear cotton underwear
avoid sex until thrush has cleared up if sex is uncomfortable

sections.title: Don’t
paragraphs: do not use soaps or shower gels
do not use douches or deodorants on your vagina or penis
do not wear tight underwear or tights

sections.title: Important
paragraphs: If you have sex during treatment, be aware that antifungal creams can damage condoms and diaphragms. This means your contraception might not work.

sections.title: A pharmacist can help with thrush
paragraphs: You can buy antifungal medicine from pharmacies if you've had thrush diagnosed in the past and you know the symptoms.
A pharmacist can recommend the best treatment for you. Ask if they have a private area to talk if you're embarrassed.
You should not use antifungal medicine more than twice in 6 months without speaking to a pharmacist or doctor.

sections.title: What causes thrush
paragraphs: Thrush is not classed as a sexually transmitted infection (STI), but it can be triggered by sex or, less often, passed on during sex.
Thrush is caused by a fungus called candida that is normally harmless.
Thrush tends to grow in warm, moist conditions and develops if the balance of bacteria changes.
